item.title: NYHQ2005-2204
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
Children smile, at a nonformal education centre in Kinsenso, a poor settlement on the outskirts of Kinshasha, the capital. The UNICEF-supported centre provides basic education to children who have left traditional schools for a variety of reasons. Part of the UNICEF logo is visible on the banner behind them.
In 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the situation for children remains precarious. The nation is among the least developed in the world, with 80 per cent of its population living below the poverty line and some 40,000 children living on the street. Instability continues to hamper relief efforts in the north-eastern region, where a seven-year civil war has killed 4 million Congolese, many from starvation and disease. UNICEF continues to work with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of children and women displaced by the conflict, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts. An improved security situation in some areas has permitted greater access to children in conflict zones, while allowing some resources to be redirected toward health, education and protection in other parts of the country. Assistance has also been scaled up for children living or working on the streets, orphans and child labourers. UNICEF supports early childhood development and primary education, especially for girls and children whose education has been disrupted by conflict; immunization, nutrition and growth-monitoring programmes; HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention training; and ongoing provision of emergency health, water and sanitation services.

item.title: NYHQ2005-0439
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
Boys raise their hands to shield their faces and their identities as former child soldiers, at a UNICEF-supported Centre de Transit et Orientation (CTO), a shelter and reintegration centre for recently demobilized child soldiers, in the eastern town of Goma, capital of North Kivu Province. The CTO provides medical and psychosocial care, as well as family tracing and reunification services. Nationwide, over 33,000 child soldiers remain active.
In March 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), insecurity and massive population displacements continue to challenge relief efforts in the eastern part of the country. An upsurge in violence in the resource-rich Ituri region, including the killing in February of nine MONUC (United Nations Organization Mission in the DRC) peacekeepers, led to a temporary suspension in humanitarian aid to tens of thousands of displaced civilians. Over two-thirds of the displaced are children and women. As aid resumes, the number of displaced continues to grow: up to 88,000 are registered in camps but many more are assumed to be in need of shelter. Some 6 million people throughout the north-eastern region are affected by the ongoing conflict. Hundreds of thousands are victimized in atrocities committed with impunity. Recruitment of child soldiers by all military factions continues. Rape of girls and women is a widespread weapon of war, terrorizing the population and increasing HIV prevalence. This regional fighting is part of a seven-year conflict in which up to 5 million Congolese have died from starvation, disease and warfare. UNICEF is working with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of displaced children and women, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts and other health, water and sanitation, education and protection initiatives in the region.

item.title: NYHQ2005-2126
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
A girl waits at a health centre in Kisangani, capital of the north-eastern Province Orientale. UNICEF provides the centre with essential drugs and vaccines, medical supplies, mosquito bednets for pregnant women and children under five, training for health workers, as well as bicycles and motor bikes for outreach and supervision.
In 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the situation for children remains precarious. The nation is among the least developed in the world, with 80 per cent of its population living below the poverty line and some 40,000 children living on the street. Instability continues to hamper relief efforts in the north-eastern region, where a seven-year civil war has killed 4 million Congolese, many from starvation and disease. item.title: Children gather to play and learn at one of the three Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF Education/Child Protection partner RHA in Punia. Offering a safe place to gather outside of school, the CFS can serve as a point of refuge and one in which to share and overcome that which they may have experienced in the course of conflict and displacement. Following heavy fighting in early 2013 between the Raia Mutomboki (RM) rebel group and the Congolese Army (FARDC) more than 55,000 people were displaced into the forests and indigenous villages of Punia Territory, Maniema Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Despite the logistical challenges of providing aid in an area inaccessible by car, and with persistent threats to security, UNICEF RRMP partner NRC immediately intervened to provide a multi-sectorial evaluation (MSA) allowing for a coordinated, rapid response between UN, INGO and Local NGO partners. By July, In addition to the rehabilitation/construction of 15 water sources, establishment of 22 water chlorination points and construction of 48 latrines, UNICEF partners succeeded in providing emergency non-food item (NFI) support to more then 5,700 households (approximately 28,000 people) emergency health services to more than 15,000 and Education / Child Protection support to the teachers and pupils of 65 separate schools in the affected area. With the area now largely under the control of the national authorities the vast majority of the population has returned home.

item.title: Children play at the Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF partner AVSI in the Bulengo IDP site. The CFS provide a safe environment for children to gather for recreational and educational activities while not in school.A delegation of Emergency Directors including UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, OCHA Operations Director John Ging, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in DRC Moustapha Soumare and high-level representatives from WFP, WHO, FAO and UNHCR visited the Bulengo Spontaneous Site just outside Goma on Tuesday, October 22, 2013 to witness the multi-agency humanitarian response in the largest single displacement site in North Kivu. Home to approximately 55,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Bulengo has experienced a massive influx of IDPs since November 2012 when thousands fled towards Goma during fighting between the M23 and Congolese Army (FARDC). Since then, numerous waves of displacement have resulted from clashes between the FARDC and M23, Nyatura and APCLS rebel groups. Coming mainly from the Masisi and Rutshuru territories, the IDPs in Bulengo represent some of the more than 1 million currently displaced in North Kivu. Coordinated by IOM and managed by Première Urgence ? Aide Médicale International (PU-AMI) and Danish Refugee Council (DRC) residents of the Bulengo Site have received Non-Food Item (NFI) support from the UNICEF-OCHA RRMP in December 2012, Food and Nutrition support from WFP and World Vision, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support from Oxfam and Mercy Corps, Education and Child Protection support from UNICEF partner AVSI and Health support from MSF Belgium.
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Children play at the Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF partner AVSI in the Bulengo IDP site. The CFS provide a safe environment for children to gather for recreational and educational activities while not in school.
A delegation of Emergency Directors including UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, OCHA Operations Director John Ging, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in DRC Moustapha Soumare and high-level representatives from WFP, WHO, FAO and UNHCR visited the Bulengo Spontaneous Site just outside Goma on Tuesday, October 22, 2013 to witness the multi-agency humanitarian response in the largest single displacement site in North Kivu.
Home to approximately 55,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Bulengo has experienced a massive influx of IDPs since November 2012 when thousands fled towards Goma during fighting between the M23 and Congolese Army (FARDC). Since then, numerous waves of displacement have resulted from clashes between the FARDC and M23, Nyatura and APCLS rebel groups. Coming mainly from the Masisi and Rutshuru territories, the IDPs in Bulengo represent some of the more than 1 million currently displaced in North Kivu.
Coordinated by IOM and managed by Première Urgence – Aide Médicale International (PU-AMI) and Danish Refugee Council (DRC) residents of the Bulengo Site have received Non-Food Item (NFI) support from the UNICEF-OCHA RRMP in December 2012, Food and Nutrition support from WFP and World Vision, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support from Oxfam and Mercy Corps, Education and Child Protection support from UNICEF partner AVSI and Health support from MSF Belgium.

item.title: Sotraki Temporary Site, Goma? 8th CEPAC, a local NGO operating in Goma distributes BP-5 buscuits and Plumpy nut to malnourished children living in the Sotraki site? Following months of relative peace after the takeover of Goma by the M23 rebels in November, 2012, fighting once again broke out on the edge of Goma between the M23 and the Congolese Army (FARDC) in May, 2013. Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites. With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages.NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.
item.dc:creator: adrien

Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.
In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites.
With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages. NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.

item.title: On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.
item.dc:creator: Justine

item.title: The ECHO-funded UNHAS helicopter departs Kasika, Mwenga Territory.__The IASC Emergency Directors Group visit humanitarian activities in Mwenga, Territory, South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo on Thursday, October 24, 2013.With numerous armed confrontations continuing in eastern DRC, more than 2.7 million are currently displaced. The visit of Emergency Directors, including OCHA Operations Director John Ging and UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, among others, is meant to help create a shared understanding of challenges within the various humanitarian agencies present, as well as to help identify solutions to operational gaps. Traveling by ECHO-funded helicopter to Kasika, Mwenga, the Directors delegation visited an ECHO-funded Food Fair implemented by AVSI, a FAO-funded food security project, a health center supported by UNICEF carrying out support to malnourished children, as well as a food distribution funded by WFP and implemented by World Vision.
item.dc:creator: Justine

item.title: UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilitiesGoma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - ?The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it?s very difficult for him to walk,? says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal. ?He?s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,? Vumilia adds. 8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand. The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu?s capital Goma. He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. Restoring dignityThere are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC. Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities. So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF?s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. ?Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,? underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. ?Their dignity is restored,? she adds.RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters?including host families?while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families. In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma. ?Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,? Katungo explains. ?That?s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,? she adds. Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.[END]
item.dc:creator: adrien

He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December.
Restoring dignity There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC. Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities. So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF’s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. “Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,” underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. “Their dignity is restored,” she adds. RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012 The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters—including host families—while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families. In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services. The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma. “Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,” Katungo explains. “That’s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,” she adds. Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin. [END]

item.title: Elena Locatelli :C'est avec une grande joie que l'UNICEF s'associe ce jour à Goma à la remise officielle symbolique des matériels et équipements par le Ministre de la Santé Publique, au Gouverneur de la province du Nord Kivu.Pour la première fois, le Gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé comme donateur direct avec l'UNICEF à acheter, dans le cadre du Projet d?équipement des structures sanitaires (PESS), les équipements médicaux pour couvrir les besoins en matériels médico-sanitaires de 200 hôpitaux généraux de référence et 1000 centres de santé dans les 11 provinces du pays en trois phases d'ici à mi-2015. A ce stade, dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2, les équipements pour 132 hôpitaux et 660 centres de santé ont été livrés ou sont en cours d'achat, à travers la centrale d'achat de l'UNICEF à Copenhague.Le volume financier contribué par le gouvernement à travers l'UNICEF dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2 s'élève à 29.8 millions de dollars américains.La troisième phase, planifiée pour 2014, ciblera 68 Hôpitaux et 340 centres de sante additionnels et coutera 22 millions de dollars, que le gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé à financer.L'acheminement des équipements a représenté des défis, avec environ 140 containers de 40 pieds (67 mètres cubes) expédies par bateaux et partiellement par avions en RDC pour la première phase seule, et 420 containers attendus au total pour les trois phases. L'UNICEF est responsable pour l'ensemble de la chaine d'approvisionnement depuis la commande, jusqu'au transport maritime et aerien, a la réception et l'entreposage, le conditionnement, l'évaluation techniques des structures cibles, la distribution in-country, et la formation des bénéficiaires finaux pendant l'installation dans les sites. Les matériels et équipements qui viennent d?être remis par le Ministère de la santé Publique vont renforcer le système de santé et aider à une meilleure prise en charge de la population. L'espoir de l'UNICEF est que grâce à cette volonté politique nationale forte, tous les enfants et leurs mamans, même ceux des zones les plus reculées de RDC puissent avoir accès aux soins de qualité permettant de vaincre les principales causes de mortalité. Ces efforts du gouvernement congolais sont une contribution significative à la « promesse renouvelée » pour l'avancement du pays vers les OMD 4 et 5, qui vise à sauver 430 000 vies d?enfants de 0 à 5 ans et 7 900 vies de mères d?ici fin 2015.Nous saisissons cette occasion pour féliciter le gouvernement et l'encourager à poursuivre ses efforts en faveur de la santé de la mère et de l?enfant dans le cadre de l?approche « Naître, grandir, progresser ».
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
Elena Locatelli :
C'est avec une grande joie que l'UNICEF s'associe ce jour à Goma à la remise officielle symbolique des matériels et équipements par le Ministre de la Santé Publique, au Gouverneur de la province du Nord Kivu.
Pour la première fois, le Gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé comme donateur direct avec l'UNICEF à acheter, dans le cadre du Projet d’équipement des structures sanitaires (PESS), les équipements médicaux pour couvrir les besoins en matériels médico-sanitaires de 200 hôpitaux généraux de référence et 1000 centres de santé dans les 11 provinces du pays en trois phases d'ici à mi-2015.
A ce stade, dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2, les équipements pour 132 hôpitaux et 660 centres de santé ont été livrés ou sont en cours d'achat, à travers la centrale d'achat de l'UNICEF à Copenhague.
Le volume financier contribué par le gouvernement à travers l'UNICEF dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2 s'élève à 29.8 millions de dollars américains.
La troisième phase, planifiée pour 2014, ciblera 68 Hôpitaux et 340 centres de sante additionnels et coutera 22 millions de dollars, que le gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé à financer.
L'acheminement des équipements a représenté des défis, avec environ 140 containers de 40 pieds (67 mètres cubes) expédies par bateaux et partiellement par avions en RDC pour la première phase seule, et 420 containers attendus au total pour les trois phases. L'UNICEF est responsable pour l'ensemble de la chaine d'approvisionnement depuis la commande, jusqu'au transport maritime et aerien, a la réception et l'entreposage, le conditionnement, l'évaluation techniques des structures cibles, la distribution in-country, et la formation des bénéficiaires finaux pendant l'installation dans les sites.
Les matériels et équipements qui viennent d’être remis par le Ministère de la santé Publique vont renforcer le système de santé et aider à une meilleure prise en charge de la population.
L'espoir de l'UNICEF est que grâce à cette volonté politique nationale forte, tous les enfants et leurs mamans, même ceux des zones les plus reculées de RDC puissent avoir accès aux soins de qualité permettant de vaincre les principales causes de mortalité.
Ces efforts du gouvernement congolais sont une contribution significative à la « promesse renouvelée » pour l'avancement du pays vers les OMD 4 et 5, qui vise à sauver 430 000 vies d’enfants de 0 à 5 ans et 7 900 vies de mères d’ici fin 2015.
Nous saisissons cette occasion pour féliciter le gouvernement et l'encourager à poursuivre ses efforts en faveur de la santé de la mère et de l’enfant dans le cadre de l’approche « Naître, grandir, progresser ».

item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilities Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - “The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it’s very difficult for him to walk,” says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal. “He’s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,” Vumilia adds.
8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand. The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu’s capital Goma. He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December.
Restoring dignity There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC. Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities. So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF’s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. “Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,” underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. “Their dignity is restored,” she adds. RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012 The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters—including host families—while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families. In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services. The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma. “Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,” Katungo explains. “That’s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,” she adds. Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin. [END]

item.title: On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.
item.dc:creator: Justine

item.title: UNICEF DRC 2013 Morton Smile of the Week 06Feb2014
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
March 15, 2013 Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.
Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando.
From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.
Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.
Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

item.title: NYHQ2012-0883
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
Zainab [NAME CHANGED], 16, stands in a UNICEF-assisted transit centre for recently released former child soldiers, in the town of Ndele, capital of the northern Bamingui-Bangoran Prefecture. Wanting to avenge the death of her fiancé, Zainab joined an armed group but, once recruited, was frequently sexually abused by male soldiers. She is now recovering at the centre, where she receives basic business training to pursue her dream of owning a restaurant. All she talks about is going back home, said a child protection specialist who works at the centre.
From 18 to 23 August 2012 in the Central African Republic (CAR), UNICEF Advocate for Children Affected by War Ishmael Beah met with children recently released from participation in armed groups, in the northern town of NDele, near the border with Chad. The children are presently staying at a UNICEF-assisted transit centre run by the Danish Refugee Council. Mr. Beah also witnessed the release of 10 children from the armed group Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace (CPJP), at a nearby military camp. Mr. Beah was himself forcibly recruited into armed forces during the civil war in his country, Sierra Leone. He was released from these forces in 1996 with assistance from UNICEF  a story he recounts in his 2007 bestselling book, A Long Way Gone: Memoirs of a Boy Soldier. Mr. Beah shared some of these experiences with the children in NDele and read them portions of his book. When you are conditioned to function in war, it takes time to know that something else is possible. I went through that myself, he told the children. He later remarked, These children have been through so much, but their release marks just the beginning. Many of the children have little to return to [and] urgently require special care over the long term. The transit centre aims to help the children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence they have been subjected to and participated in. It provides counselling support, basic education, sport, cultural activities and vocational skills training for 45 children aged 1018 years. Three of the children presently at the centre are girls. Amid proliferating conflicts in the Central African Republic  one of the worlds poorest countries  numerous national and foreign armed groups use children to work as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, amongst other roles. In Bangui, the capital, Mr. Beah also met with government and other officials to press for additional support to ensure an end to the forcible recruitment of children into armed groups. Worldwide, thousands of children continue to be deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation and reintegration efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to integrate back into their communities.

item.title: (Right) Clemence [NAME CHANGED], 16, holds her mother?s hand while visiting her at her home, in Bria, capital of Haute-Kotto Prefecture. After four years in the Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace rebel group, she was released about two weeks ago with assistance from UNICEF. Though she currently stays in a UNICEF-supported transit centre for recently released former child soldiers, also in Bria, she visits her mother regularly. The centre provides shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families.In December 2012 in the Central African Republic, conflict continues to worsen living conditions in what is already one of the world?s poorest countries, with one of the highest rates of under-five child mortality. Vital infrastructure has been destroyed, severely constricting access to healthcare, education and other basic services. Additionally, numerous national and foreign armed groups continue to forcibly recruit children, using them as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, among other roles. UNICEF supports transit centres that help children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence to which they have been subjected and in which they have participated. The centres provide shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families. Worldwide, thousands of children remain deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to reintegrate with their communities.

item.title: ER EP Magulu Nyembo on lving in harmony at school

item.title: UNICEF Deputy Executive Director Yoka Brandt, WFP Deputy Executive Director Ramiro Lopes da Silva and UNHCR Assistant High Commissioner for Operations Janet Lim visit Lagabo, an IDP site 30km outside Bunia, in the Ituri Territory of Province Orentale, Democratic Republic of Congo.Calling on the international community to sustain support to the country?s large-scale humanitarian crisis, the group visited UNICEF Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) Education and WASH activities, as well as a UNICEF supported health center and WFP Food Distribution.In August 2013, fighting between the national army (FARDC) and local militias lead to the displacement of more than 120,000 in the Irumu Territory; Lagabo grew in a matter of days from few hundred people to a village hosting approximately 23,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs). At Lapa Primary School, which grew from 11 to 1,395 students at the height of displacement, the UNICEF-OCHA led Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) program responded constructing 9 classrooms training teachers and providing school kits. In addition, two water sources were rehabilitated and support provided to the health center.Yoka Brandt: ?I was impressed by Lagabo?s commitment and determination, and will remember well the message echoed by numerous people throughout the day: ?There can be no development without peace.? This day was a chance to better understand the harsh realities of displacement as we search for ways in which to continue to improve our joint efforts.?
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
UNICEF Deputy Executive Director Yoka Brandt, WFP Deputy Executive Director Ramiro Lopes da Silva and UNHCR Assistant High Commissioner for Operations Janet Lim visit Lagabo, an IDP site 30km outside Bunia, in the Ituri Territory of Province Orentale, Democratic Republic of Congo.
Calling on the international community to sustain support to the country’s large-scale humanitarian crisis, the group visited UNICEF Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) Education and WASH activities, as well as a UNICEF supported health center and WFP Food Distribution.
In August 2013, fighting between the national army (FARDC) and local militias lead to the displacement of more than 120,000 in the Irumu Territory; Lagabo grew in a matter of days from few hundred people to a village hosting approximately 23,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs).
At Lapa Primary School, which grew from 11 to 1,395 students at the height of displacement, the UNICEF-OCHA led Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) program responded constructing 9 classrooms training teachers and providing school kits. In addition, two water sources were rehabilitated and support provided to the health center.
Yoka Brandt: “I was impressed by Lagabo’s commitment and determination, and will remember well the message echoed by numerous people throughout the day: “There can be no development without peace.” This day was a chance to better understand the harsh realities of displacement as we search for ways in which to continue to improve our joint efforts.”

item.title: UNICEF DRC 2013 Brett Morton.
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
Following completion of her shopping, a mother waits for her friends outside the NFI Fair in Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC carried out by UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI in May, 2013.
Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando.
From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.
Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.
Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

item.title: 140402095744 (2) (640x426)
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Claudine prepares lunch for her two children and husband in Niacajanga, North Kivu.
Working to help communities living in areas of historic displacement and return and communities at risk of inter/intra community conflict in eastern DRC, the UNICEF “Community Resilience and Participation for Children” program is now being carried out by UNICEF partners in eastern DRC.
Built upon lessons learned from previous programs assisting returnees, the program works in communities like Niacajanga to improve the health and education systems, support vocational training and micro enterprise groups and improve local governance and conflict mitigation systems. Projecting to support 1.3 million people like Claudine and her family, the program strives to consolidate improvements in stability and help insulate communities from further instability.
From the Photographer: On Wednesday the OCHA Donors Support Group visited Niacajanga as part of their visit in DRC. As an occasion for key donors to see some of the activities they fund, many were impressed with the level of involvement by community members like Claudine.
Accompanying the delegation was Claus Sorensen, the Director General of ECHO, who is a key donor to UNICEF DRC. Mr. Sorensen had commented previously that “You cannot do the work we do without going to the field. It is only by actually seeing the situation and trying to put yourself in other peoples' shoes that you understand their needs.”
To me, this was what was so important about the day; it was an invaluable opportunity for our donors to see the villages and discuss issues with the people we’re working with and for. Above all, it was an opportunity to see firsthand how important it is that this work continues.

Above all, it was an opportunity to see firsthand how important it is that this work continues.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1396432664;s:9:"copyright";s:24:"©UNICEF DRC/2014/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}

item.title: UNICEF RDC 2013 Morton RRMP
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
March 17, 2013 Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.
Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center.
“I’m really content with what I purchased,” Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. “Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.” __
Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando.
From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.
Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.
Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.
Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center.
“I’m really content with what I purchased,” Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. “Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.”

item.title: UNICEF RDC 2013 Morton Situation Humanitaire Mars 2014
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
May 16, 2013. UNICEF partner TPO operates two Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) in Mwenga Center, South Kivu, DRC, providing nearly 4,000 children aged 2-18 with a protected environment in which to gather, supervised by staff trained in child protection. Designed to support and encourage their freedom of expression, right to play, to learn, to be stimulated and to develop their capacities in a friendly and warm environment, Child Friendly Spaces also offer an opportunity to sensitize children on basic issues like hygiene and sanitation, as well as the importance of education.
“UNICEF funds our project in Mwenga, which is designed to reinforce the capacity of the community to respond on behalf of their vulnerable children,” explains Rwaha Rwakenga, a Social Worker for TPO, a Uganda-based NGO. “One day we’re not going to be here, but the community must carry on with serving and protecting their children. For this reason the community is involved not only in the CFS, but also in trainings and sensitizations to make sure everyone in the community is aware of the importance of this for their children.”

item.title: 130528100749 (640x428)
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Buhimba Temporary Site. Following months of relative peace after the takeover of Goma by the M23 rebels in November, 2012, fighting once again broke out on the edge of Goma between the M23 and the Congolese Army (FARDC) in May, 2013. Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.
In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites.
With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages. NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.
